\subsection{Application to perturbation theory and discussion of related work}
The present results apply to perturbation theory~\cite{kato,baumgartel},
and specially, to the singular case
in which a matrix with multiple eigenvalues
is perturbed. The latter situation is the object of the theory developed 
by Vi\v sik and Ljusternik~\cite{vishik}
and completed by Lidski\u\i~\cite{lidskii},
see~\cite{mbo97} for a survey.
The goal
of this theory is to give a direct characterization
of the exponents, without computing
the Newton polytope of the characteristic polynomial.
The theorem of~\cite{lidskii} solves this problem under
some genericity assumptions, requiring the non-vanishing
of certain Schur complements. The question of solving
degenerate instance of Lidsk\u\i's theorem has been
considered in particular, by Ma and Edelman~\cite{maedelman} and Najman~\cite{najman}, and also by Moro, Burke and Overton in~\cite{mbo97}. Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen} 
generalize the theorem of Lidski\u\i, as they allow one
to solve degenerate instances in which the Schur complements
needed in Lidski\u\i's construction are no longer defined.



The present train of thoughts originates from a work of Friedland~\cite{friedland}, 
who showed that a certain deformation of the Perron root of a nonnegative matrix, in terms of Hadamard powers, converges to the maximal circuit mean of the matrix, a.k.a., the maximal tropical eigenvalue. 
Then, in~\cite{ABG96}, we showed that the limiting Perron eigenvector,
along the same deformation, can also be characterized by tropical means,
under a nondegeneracy condition. An early version of the present Theorems~\ref{th-major-cont} and~\ref{th-gen=} appeared as Theorem~3.8 of the authors' preprint~\cite{abg04b}. There, we also gave a generalization of the theorem of Lidski\u\i, in which the exponents of the first order asymptotics of the eigenvalues are given by the tropical eigenvalues of certain tropical Schur complements and their coefficients are given by some associated usual Schur complements like in the true Lidski\u\i\ theorem. 
However, some singular cases remained, 
see for instance Example~\ref{example-lidski},
motivating the introduction of matrix polynomial eigenproblems in further works.
The results of Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen} were announced without proof in the note~\cite{abg04}. 
Therefore, the present article is, for some part, a survey of results which have not appeared previously in the form of a journal article. It also provides a 
general presentation of eigenvalues in terms of valuation theory,
with several new results or refinements, like the general
majorization inequality for the eigenvalues of matrix polynomials,
Theorem~\ref{th-major-pencil}. 
The interest of this presentation is that it explains better the relation between the results obtained here, or in eigenvalues perturbation theory, for the non-archimedean valuations of matrix entries and eigenvalues, with their analogues for archimedean valuations, like the modulus map, or for
some generalization of the notion of  archimedean valuation which includes
in particular matrix norms.

Indeed, the latter works have motivated
a more recent work by Akian, Gaubert and Marchesini, who showed in~\cite{AGM2014a}, that one form of the theorem of Friedland concerning the Perron or dominant root carries over to all eigenvalues:  the sequence of moduli of all eigenvalues of a matrix is weakly log-majorized by the sequence of tropical eigenvalues, up to certain combinatorial coefficients. Therefore, the result there
can be thought of as a analogue of Theorem~\ref{th-major-eig} or~\ref{th-major-cont}
for the modulus archimedean valuation.
Also, the results of~\cite{abg04b,abg04} have
been at the origin of the application of tropical methods
by Gaubert and Sharify to the numerical computation and estimation
of eigenvalues~\cite{posta09,sharifyphd}, based on the norms of
matrix polynomial coefficients.
This is a subject of current interest,
with work by Akian, Bini, Gaubert, Hammarling, Noferini, Sharify, and Tisseur~\cite{binisharify,hamarling,SharifyTisseur,logmajorization2013}. 






The present results provide a further illustration
of the role of tropical algebra in asymptotic analysis,
which was recognized by Maslov~\cite[Ch.~VIII]{maslov73}.
He observed that WKB-type or large deviation type asymptotics lead
to limiting equations, like Hamilton-Jacobi equations,
of a tropical nature.
This observation is at the origin
of idempotent analysis~\cite{maslov92,maslov92a,maslovkolokoltsov95,litvinov00}.
The same deformation has been identified by Viro~\cite{viro},
in relation with the patchworking method he developed
for real algebraic curves. 

Note that all the perturbation results described or recalled
above study sufficient conditions for the possible computation
of first order asymptotics of some roots when an information 
on the first order asymptotics of the data is only available.
However, when all the Puiseux series expansion of the data is known,
Puiseux theorem allows one to compute without any condition
all the Puiseux series expansion.
In the context of matrix polynomials, 
Murota~\cite{murota}, gave an algorithm to compute the Puiseux series 
expansions of the eigenvalues of a matrix polynomial depending polynomially
in the parameter ${\epsilon}$, avoiding the explicit computation of the
characteristic polynomial.
As for Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}, 
his algorithm relies on a parametric optimal assignment problem.































































































































































The present work builds on tropical spectral theory. It has been inspired by the analogy with nonnegative matrix theory, of which Hans Schneider was a master. We gratefully acknowledge our debt to him.

of eigenvalues~\cite{posta09,sharifyphd}, based on the norms of
matrix polynomial coefficients.
This is a subject of current interest,
with work by Akian, Bini, Gaubert, Hammarling, Noferini, Sharify, and Tisseur~\cite{binisharify,hamarling,SharifyTisseur,logmajorization2013}. 






The present results provide a further illustration
of the role of tropical algebra in asymptotic analysis,
which was recognized by Maslov~\cite[Ch.~VIII]{maslov73}.
He observed that WKB-type or large deviation type asymptotics lead
to limiting equations, like Hamilton-Jacobi equations,
of a tropical nature.
This observation is at the origin
of idempotent analysis~\cite{maslov92,maslov92a,maslovkolokoltsov95,litvinov00}.
The same deformation has been identified by Viro~\cite{viro},
in relation with the patchworking method he developed
for real algebraic curves. 

Note that all the perturbation results described or recalled
above study sufficient conditions for the possible computation
of first order asymptotics of some roots when an information 
on the first order asymptotics of the data is only available.
However, when all the Puiseux series expansion of the data is known,
Puiseux theorem allows one to compute without any condition
all the Puiseux series expansion.
In the context of matrix polynomials, 
Murota~\cite{murota}, gave an algorithm to compute the Puiseux series 
expansions of the eigenvalues of a matrix polynomial depending polynomially
in the parameter ${\epsilon}$, avoiding the explicit computation of the
characteristic polynomial.
As for Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}, 
his algorithm relies on a parametric optimal assignment problem.































































































































































The present work builds on tropical spectral theory. It has been inspired by the analogy with nonnegative matrix theory, of which Hans Schneider was a master. We gratefully acknowledge our debt to him.












\section{Min-plus polynomials and Newton polygons} \label{sec-minpol}

We first recall some elementary facts
concerning formal polynomials and polynomial functions
over the min-plus semifield, and their relation
with Newton polygons. 

The {\em {min-plus semifield}}\index{{min-plus semifield}}, ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$, is the set
${\mathbb{R}}\cup\{+\infty\}$ equipped with the addition
$(a,b)\mapsto \min(a,b)$, denoted  $a\oplus b$, and the multiplication
$(a,b)\mapsto a+b$, denoted  $a\otimes b$ or $ab$.
We shall denote by ${\mathbbold{0}}=+\infty$
and ${\mathbbold{1}}=0$ the zero and unit elements of ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$, respectively.
The familiar algebraic constructions and conventions carry
out to the min-plus context with obvious changes. For instance, if $A,B$ are
matrices of compatible dimensions
with entries in ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$, we shall denote by $AB$ the matrix
product with entries $(AB)_{ij}


=\bigoplus_{k} A_{ik}B_{kj}
=\min_{k} (A_{ik}+B_{kj})$, we denote by $A^k$ the $k$th min-plus matrix power of $A$, etc.

Moreover, if $x\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}\setminus\{{\mathbbold{0}}\}$, then
we will denote by $x^{-1}$ the inverse of $x$ for the $\otimes$ law, 
which is nothing but $-x$, with the conventional notation.





The reader
seeking information on the min-plus semifield
may consult~\cite{cuning,maslov92,bcoq,maslovkolokoltsov95,abg05,butkovicbook}.














We denote by ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}[{\mathsf{Y}}]$ the semiring of formal polynomials with 
coefficients in ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$ in the indeterminate ${\mathsf{Y}}$: a
{\em {formal polynomial}}\index{{formal polynomial}} $P\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}[{\mathsf{Y}}]$ is nothing but
a sequence $(P_k)_{k\in{\mathbb{N}}}\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{\mathbb{N}}$ such that $P_k={\mathbbold{0}}$
for all but finitely many values of $k$. Formal
polynomials are equipped with the entry-wise
sum, $(P\oplus Q)_k=P_k\oplus Q_k$, 
and the Cauchy product, $(P Q)_k=\bigoplus_{0\leq i\leq k}P_i Q_{k-i}$.
As usual, we denote a formal polynomial
$P$ as a formal sum, $P=\bigoplus_{k=0}^{\infty} P_k {\mathsf{Y}}^k$.
We also define the {\em {degree}}\index{{degree}} and {\em {valuation}}\index{{valuation}} of $P$:
$\deg P=\sup{\{{k\in {\mathbb{N}}}\mid\,{P_k\neq {\mathbbold{0}}}\}}$,
${\operatorname{val}} P=\inf{\{{k\in {\mathbb{N}}}\mid\,{P_k\neq {\mathbbold{0}}}\}}$
($\deg P=-\infty$ and ${\operatorname{val}} P=+\infty$ if $P={\mathbbold{0}}$).
To any $P\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}[{\mathsf{Y}}]$, 
we associate the {\em {polynomial function}}\index{{polynomial function}} ${\widehat{{P}}}:{\mathbb{R}}_{\min}\to{\mathbb{R}}_{\min},\; y\mapsto {\widehat{{P}}}(y)=
\bigoplus_{k=0}^{\infty} P_k y^k$, that is, with the

\begin{proof}
We first prove the ``only if'' part. 
If ${\mathsf{R} ({P})}=(c_1\leq \cdots \leq c_n)$,
then ${\overline{{P}}}={\overline{{P}}}_n ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_1)\cdots ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_n)$ and,
by Theorem~\ref{th21},
${\overline{{P}}}_{n-i}= {\overline{{P}}}_n c_1\cdots c_i$ for all $i=1,\ldots n$.
Recall that $P$ defines a map $x\mapsto P(x)$ by~\eqref{pasafunction}.
By definition of ${\operatorname{vex}} P$,
the epigraph of ${\operatorname{vex}} P$, ${\operatorname{epi}} {\operatorname{vex}} P$,
is the convex hull of the epigraph of $P$,
${\operatorname{epi}} P$. By a classical result~\cite[Cor~18.3.1]{rockafellar}, if $S$ is a 
set with convex hull $C$, any extreme point of $C$ belongs
to $S$. Let us apply this to $S={\operatorname{epi}} P$ and
$C={\operatorname{epi}} {\operatorname{vex}} P$.
Since 
$c_i={\overline{{P}}}_{n-i}  ({\overline{{P}}}_{n-i+1})^{-1}$,
the piecewise affine map ${\operatorname{vex}} P$
changes its slope at any 
point $n-i$ such that 
$c_i<c_{i+1}$.
Thus, any point $(n-i,{\operatorname{vex}}{P}(n-i))$ with $c_i<c_{i+1}$
is an extreme point of ${\operatorname{epi}} {\operatorname{vex}} P$,
which implies that $(n-i,{\operatorname{vex}}{P}(n-i))\in {\operatorname{epi}} P$,
i.e., $P_{n-i}\leq {\operatorname{vex}}{P}(n-i)={\overline{P}}_{n-i}$. Since
the other inequality is trivial by definition of the convex hull, we
have $P_{n-i}={\overline{{P}}}_{n-i}$. 
Obviously, $P$ and ${\overline{P}}$ have the same
degree, which is equal to $n$, and they have the same
valuation, $k$. Then, $(n,{\operatorname{vex}} P(n))$
and $(k,{\operatorname{vex}} P(k))$ are extreme points
of ${\operatorname{epi}} {\operatorname{vex}} P$, and by the preceding argument,
$P_n={\overline{P}}_n$, and $P_k={\overline{P}}_k$.
Hence, $P_0={\overline{P}}_0$, if $k=0$,
and $P_0={\overline{P}}_0=+\infty$, if $k>0$.
We have shown ~\eqref{carac-ci1},
together with the last statement of the lemma.
Since ${\overline{{P}}}_n=P_n$ and $P\geq {\overline{{P}}}$, we also obtain 
$P\geq P_n ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_1) \cdots ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_n)$.

and that~\eqref{carac-ci1} holds. Since $Q=P_n ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_1) \cdots

$P\mapsto {\overline{{P}}}$ is monotone, we must have ${\overline{{P}}}\geq {\overline{{Q}}}=Q$.
Hence, $ P \geq {\overline{{P}}}\geq Q$ and since $P_{n-i}=Q_{n-i}$ 
for all $i$ as in~\eqref{carac-ci1}, we must have $P_{n-i}={\overline{{P}}}_{n-i}=

have ${\operatorname{vex}}{P}=Q$. Hence ${\overline{{P}}}=Q$
and ${\mathsf{R} ({P})}={\mathsf{R} ({{\overline{{P}}}})}={\mathsf{R} ({Q})}=(c_1,\ldots , c_n)$.

\begin{proposition}[See~{\cite[Th.~2.1.1]{kapranov}}]\label{prop-kap}
Let ${\mathbb{K}}$ be an algebraically closed field with a (non-archimedean) valuation $\nu$
and let ${\mathcal{P}}=\sum_{k=0}^n{\mathcal{P}}_k {\mathsf{Y}}^k\in {\mathbb{K}}[{\mathsf{Y}}]$, with ${\mathcal{P}}_n=1$. Then, the 
valuations of the roots of ${\mathcal{P}}$ (counted with multiplicities)
coincide with the roots of the min-plus polynomial $\nu({\mathcal{P}}):=\bigoplus_{k=0}^n\nu({\mathcal{P}}_k){\mathsf{Y}}^k$.
\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let ${\mathcal{Y}}_1,\ldots,{\mathcal{Y}}_n$
denote the roots of ${\mathcal{P}}$, ordered by nondecreasing valuation,
$c_i:=\nu({\mathcal{Y}}_i)$, so that $c_1\leq \cdots \leq c_n$,
$Q:=\bigoplus_{k=0}^nc_1\dots c_k{\mathsf{Y}}^{n-k}$, and $P:=\nu({\mathcal{P}})$. Observe that 
$P_n=Q_n={\mathbbold{1}}$, and $Q=({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_1)\dots ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_n)$.

we get $\nu({\mathcal{P}}_{n-k})\geq \nu({\mathcal{Y}}_1\cdots {\mathcal{Y}}_k)=c_1\cdots c_k$, and so $P\geq Q$, and $P_n=Q_n$. Moreover, 
if $c_k<c_{k+1}$ or $k=n$, ${\mathcal{Y}}_{1}\cdots {\mathcal{Y}}_{k}$ is the only
term in the sum $(-1)^k\sum_{i_1<\cdots<i_k}{\mathcal{Y}}_{i_1}\cdots {\mathcal{Y}}_{i_k}$,
having a minimal valuation, and so, $P_{n-k}=\nu({\mathcal{P}}_{n-k})=c_1\cdots c_k=P_nc_1\cdots c_k$.
Then, it follows from Lemma~\ref{carac-ci} that 
$R(P)= (c_1\leq \cdots \leq c_n)=(\nu({\mathcal{Y}}_1),\cdots,\nu({\mathcal{Y}}_n))$.

\begin{proposition}\label{prop-kap-pre}
Let ${\mathcal{R}}$ be a commutative ring with a quasi-valuation ${\mathsf{e}}$, and let 
${\mathcal{R}}{^\dag}$ be defined by~\eqref{defacirc}.
Let ${\mathcal{P}}=\sum_{k=0}^n{\mathcal{P}}_k {\mathsf{Y}}^k\in {\mathcal{R}}[{\mathsf{Y}}]$, with ${\mathcal{P}}_n=1$. 
Assume that ${\mathcal{P}}$ has $n$ roots (counted with multiplicities) and that 
they all belong to ${\mathcal{R}}{^\dag}$. Then, the 
images by ${\mathsf{e}}$ of the roots of ${\mathcal{P}}$ (counted with multiplicities)
coincide with the roots of the min-plus polynomial ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{P}}})}$.

\qed
\end{proposition}


\begin{theorem}\label{th-major-eig-pre}
Let ${\mathcal{R}}$ be a commutative ring with a quasi-valuation ${\mathsf{e}}$, and let 
${\mathcal{R}}{^\dag}$ be defined by~\eqref{defacirc}.
Let  ${\mathcal{A}}=({\mathcal{A}}_{ij})\in {\mathcal{R}}^{n\times n}$.
Assume that ${\mathcal{A}}$ has $n$ algebraic eigenvalues (counted with multiplicities)
and that  they all belong to ${\mathcal{R}}{^\dag}$.  
Denote by $\Lambda=(\Lambda_1\leq \cdots \leq \Lambda_n)$ 
the sequence of their images by ${\mathsf{e}}$ (counted with multiplicities). Let 
$\Gamma=(\gamma_1\leq\cdots \leq \gamma_n)$ be the sequence of 
min-plus algebraic eigenvalues of ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}})}:=({\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}_{ij}})})\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$.
Then, $\Lambda$ is weakly majorized by $\Gamma$.
\qed
\end{theorem}

The following corollary will be used in Section~\ref{sec-gen}.
\begin{corollary}\label{cor-major-eig-pre}
Let ${\mathcal{R}}$ be a commutative ring with a quasi-valuation ${\mathsf{e}}$, and let 
${\mathcal{R}}{^\dag}$ be defined by~\eqref{defacirc}.
Let  ${\mathcal{A}}=({\mathcal{A}}_{ij})\in {\mathcal{R}}^{n\times n}$.
Assume that ${\mathcal{A}}$ has $n$ algebraic eigenvalues (counted with multiplicities)
and that  they all belong to ${\mathcal{R}}{^\dag}$.  
Denote by $\Lambda=(\Lambda_1\leq \cdots \leq \Lambda_n)$ 
the sequence of their images by ${\mathsf{e}}$ (counted with multiplicities). Let 
$A\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ be such that ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}_{ij}})}\geq A_{ij}$,
for all $i,j\in [n]$, and let 
$\Gamma=(\gamma_1\leq\cdots \leq \gamma_n)$ be the sequence of 
min-plus algebraic eigenvalues of $A$.
Then, $\Lambda$ is weakly majorized by $\Gamma$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
Theorem~\ref{th-major-eig-pre} implies 
that $\Lambda {\prec^{\rm w}}\Gamma'$, where $\Gamma'$
is the sequence of min-plus algebraic eigenvalues of 
${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}})}$.
Define the min-plus polynomials $P:={\operatorname{per}} {\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}})}$ and
$Q:={\operatorname{per}} A$. Then, by definition of min-plus eigenvalues,
$\Gamma'$ is the sequence ${\mathsf{R} ({P})}$ of min-plus roots of $P$,
and $\Gamma$ is the sequence ${\mathsf{R} ({Q})}$ of min-plus roots of $Q$.
Since ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}})}_{ij}={\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}_{ij}})}\geq A_{ij}$,
for all $i,j\in [n]$, we get that $P\geq Q$, and since $P_n=Q_n$,
Lemma~\ref{minpoly-maj} shows that ${\mathsf{R} ({P})}{\prec^{\rm w}} {\mathsf{R} ({Q})}$. Hence
$\lambda {\prec^{\rm w}}\Gamma'{\prec^{\rm w}}\Gamma$, which finishes the proof.
\end{proof}

\section{A Preliminary: Newton-Puiseux Theorem with Partial Information on Valuations}

\label{sec-newton}







If $\mathcal{A}$ is a matrix with entries in the field of Puiseux series,
the knowledge of the valuations of the entries of $\mathcal{A}$ is not
enough to determine the valuations of the coefficients
of the characteristic polynomial of $\mathcal{A}$, owing to potential cancellation.

of the coefficients of a polynomial, or equivalently, 
an ``external approximation'' of the Newton polytope, 
is available. The idea that such an information on the polytope is enough
to infer a partial information on roots is classical:
in the case of archimedean valuations, 
it already appeared for instance in the work of Montel~\cite{montel}.

$A\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ be such that ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{A}}_{ij}})}\geq A_{ij}$,

$\lambda {\prec^{\rm w}}\Gamma'{\prec^{\rm w}}\Gamma$, which finishes the proof.

Theorem~\ref{th3} is a ``precise
large deviation'' version of the Newton-Puiseux theorem:
we assume only the existence of asymptotic equivalents
for the coefficients of ${\mathcal{P}}$,
and derive the existence of asymptotic equivalents
for the branches of ${\mathcal{P}}(\epsilon,y)=0$.
The Newton-Puiseux algorithm is sometimes presented
for asymptotic expansions, as in~\cite{dieu}.
The interest of the statements of Theorems~\ref{th3-local}
and~\ref{th3}, is to show that if some
coefficients are known to be negligible,
the asymptotics of the roots is determined only from the 
asymptotics of those coefficients $\mathcal{P}_i$ such that



$(i,P_i)$ is an exposed
point of the epigraph of ${\overline{{P}}}$.

Moreover, the min-plus polynomial $P=\nu({\mathcal{P}})
= {\mathsf{Y}}^3 \oplus 5{\mathsf{Y}}^2 \oplus 6{\mathsf{Y}} + 13$
is the one of Figure~\ref{minpoly},
hence its roots are $c_1=c_2=3$ and $c_3=7$.
In that case, Proposition~\ref{prop-kap} says that
the valuations of roots of ${\mathcal{P}}$ coincide with the roots of $P$.

If now  ${\mathcal{P}}={\mathsf{Y}}^3 +\frac{{\epsilon}^3}{\log {\epsilon}} {\mathsf{Y}}^2 - {\epsilon}^6 {\mathsf{Y}}+ {\epsilon}^{13}$,
the coefficient ${\mathcal{P}}_2$ of ${\mathcal{P}}$ is not in  ${\mathbb{K}}$.

In order to prove Theorems~\ref{th3-local} and \ref{th3},
we need the following standard result.


\begin{lemma}\label{cont-roots}
Let ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},{\mathsf{Y}})=\sum_{i=0}^n {\mathcal{Q}}_j({\epsilon}) {\mathsf{Y}}^j$, where the ${\mathcal{Q}}_j$ are 
continuous functions of ${\epsilon}\in [0,{\epsilon}_0)$,
assume ${\mathcal{Q}}(0,\cdot)\neq 0$ and let $d=\deg {\mathcal{Q}}(0,\cdot)\geq 0$.
Then, for any open ball $B$ containing the roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}(0,\cdot)$,
there are $d$ continuous branches ${\mathcal{Z}}_1,\ldots ,{\mathcal{Z}}_d$ defined in 
some interval $[0,{\epsilon}_1)$, with $0<{\epsilon}_1\leq{\epsilon}_0$, such that  
${\mathcal{Z}}_1({\epsilon}),\ldots ,{\mathcal{Z}}_d({\epsilon})$ are exactly the roots of 
${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$ in $B$ counted with multiplicities.
Moreover, the roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$ that are outside $B$
tend to infinity when ${\epsilon}$ goes to $0$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
We only sketch the proof, which is classical.
By the Cauchy index theorem, 
if $\gamma$ is any circle in ${\mathbb{C}}$
containing no roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,\cdot)$,
the number of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,\cdot)$
inside $\gamma$ 
is $(2\pi i)^{-1}\int_\gamma \partial_z {\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,z)({\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,z))^{-1}\,{\text{\rm {d}}}z$.
By continuity of ${\epsilon}\mapsto {\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$, 
the number of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$
inside $\gamma$ (counted with multiplicities) is constant for ${\epsilon}'$ in
some neighborhood of ${\epsilon}$. Taking $B$ as in the lemma,
$\gamma=\partial B$, and ${\epsilon}=0$, we get exactly $d$  roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$
in $B$ for ${\epsilon}'$ in some interval $[0,{\epsilon}_1)$.
Consider now a ball $B_R\supset B$ of radius $R$. 
For ${\epsilon}'$ small enough, the number of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$ in
either $B_R$ or $B$ is equal to $d$, hence
any root of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$ outside $B$ must be outside $B_R$.
This shows that the roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$ 
that do not belong to $B$ go to infinity, when ${\epsilon}'\to 0$.
Finally, by taking small balls around each root of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$,
with $0\leq {\epsilon}< {\epsilon}_1$, we see that the map which sends ${\epsilon}$
to the unordered $d$-tuple of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$ that belong to $B$,
is continuous on $[0,{\epsilon}_1)$.
By a selection theorem for unordered $d$-tuples depending continuously on a
real parameter (see for instance~\cite[Ch. II, Section~ 5, 2]{kato}),
we derive the existence of the $d$ continuous branches ${\mathcal{Z}}_1,\ldots ,{\mathcal{Z}}_d$.
\end{proof}

Indeed, applying the change of variable $y=z {\epsilon}^{c}$, 
and the division of ${\mathcal{P}}$ 
by ${\epsilon}^{{\widehat{{P}}}(c)}$, transforms the equation ${\mathcal{P}}({\epsilon},y)

\begin{lemma}\label{cont-roots}
Let ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},{\mathsf{Y}})=\sum_{i=0}^n {\mathcal{Q}}_j({\epsilon}) {\mathsf{Y}}^j$, where the ${\mathcal{Q}}_j$ are 
continuous functions of ${\epsilon}\in [0,{\epsilon}_0)$,
assume ${\mathcal{Q}}(0,\cdot)\neq 0$ and let $d=\deg {\mathcal{Q}}(0,\cdot)\geq 0$.
Then, for any open ball $B$ containing the roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}(0,\cdot)$,
there are $d$ continuous branches ${\mathcal{Z}}_1,\ldots ,{\mathcal{Z}}_d$ defined in 
some interval $[0,{\epsilon}_1)$, with $0<{\epsilon}_1\leq{\epsilon}_0$, such that  
${\mathcal{Z}}_1({\epsilon}),\ldots ,{\mathcal{Z}}_d({\epsilon})$ are exactly the roots of 
${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$ in $B$ counted with multiplicities.
Moreover, the roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$ that are outside $B$
tend to infinity when ${\epsilon}$ goes to $0$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
We only sketch the proof, which is classical.
By the Cauchy index theorem, 
if $\gamma$ is any circle in ${\mathbb{C}}$
containing no roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,\cdot)$,
the number of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,\cdot)$
inside $\gamma$ 
is $(2\pi i)^{-1}\int_\gamma \partial_z {\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,z)({\mathcal{Q}}(\epsilon,z))^{-1}\,{\text{\rm {d}}}z$.
By continuity of ${\epsilon}\mapsto {\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$, 
the number of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$
inside $\gamma$ (counted with multiplicities) is constant for ${\epsilon}'$ in
some neighborhood of ${\epsilon}$. Taking $B$ as in the lemma,
$\gamma=\partial B$, and ${\epsilon}=0$, we get exactly $d$  roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$
in $B$ for ${\epsilon}'$ in some interval $[0,{\epsilon}_1)$.
Consider now a ball $B_R\supset B$ of radius $R$. 
For ${\epsilon}'$ small enough, the number of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$ in
either $B_R$ or $B$ is equal to $d$, hence
any root of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$ outside $B$ must be outside $B_R$.
This shows that the roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon}',\cdot)$ 
that do not belong to $B$ go to infinity, when ${\epsilon}'\to 0$.
Finally, by taking small balls around each root of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$,
with $0\leq {\epsilon}< {\epsilon}_1$, we see that the map which sends ${\epsilon}$
to the unordered $d$-tuple of roots of ${\mathcal{Q}}({\epsilon},\cdot)$ that belong to $B$,
is continuous on $[0,{\epsilon}_1)$.
By a selection theorem for unordered $d$-tuples depending continuously on a
real parameter (see for instance~\cite[Ch. II, Section~ 5, 2]{kato}),
we derive the existence of the $d$ continuous branches ${\mathcal{Z}}_1,\ldots ,{\mathcal{Z}}_d$.
\end{proof}

in the sum of all ${\mathcal{Y}}_{j_1}\cdots {\mathcal{Y}}_{j_i}$,
and then $p_{n-i}=(-1)^i y_1\cdots y_i\neq 0$.
Moreover, for $i=n$, either $Y_n\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$, which implies that
$p_{0}=(-1)^n y_1\cdots y_n\neq 0$, or $Y_n={\mathbbold{0}}$, which implies
that ${\mathcal{Y}}_n=0$, ${\mathcal{P}}_0=0$ and $Q_0={\mathbbold{0}}$.
This shows that $(c_1,\ldots,c_n)=(Y_1,\ldots,Y_n)$
and $P=Q$ are as in Point~\eqref{th3-2}.

The implication~\eqref{th3-2}$\implies$\eqref{th3-1}
and the remaining part of the theorem will follow from several applications of 
Theorem~\ref{th3-local}.
We now only assume that the ${\mathcal{P}}_j\in{\mathcal{C}}$ 
satisfy Point~\eqref{th3-2} and consider
$(c_1\leq \cdots \leq c_n)={\mathsf{R} ({P})}$.
From Lemma~\ref{carac-ci} applied to $P$, we get that
$P\geq P_n ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_1)\cdots ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_n)$,
$P_{n-i}=P_n c_1\cdots c_i$
for all $i\in\{0,n\}\cup{\{{i\in \{1,\ldots , n-1\}}\mid\,{c_i< c_{i+1}}\}}$,
and ${\overline{{P}}}=P_n ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_1)\cdots ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_n)$.
It follows from~{\rm (\ref{defexp},\ref{puis0-1})}, 
that ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{P}}})}\geq P\geq P_n ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_1)\cdots ({\mathsf{Y}}\oplus c_n)$,
and from  Point~\eqref{th3-2} and~\eqref{puis0},
we get that ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{P}}})}_{n-i}= P_{n-i}$
for all $i\in\{0,n\}\cup{\{{i\in \{1,\ldots , n-1\}}\mid\,{c_i< c_{i+1}}\}}$.
Then, ${\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{P}}})}$ satifies the conditions of  Lemma~\ref{carac-ci},
which yields ${\mathsf{R} ({{\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{P}}})}})}={\mathsf{R} ({P})}$ and
${\overline{{{\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{P}}})}}}}={\overline{{P}}}$.

Let $c\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$ be  a root of $P$ with multiplicity $m$.
Then, there exists $0\leq i <n$ such that  $c=c_{i+1}=\cdots =c_{i+m}$.
Using the same arguments as in the proof of Theorem~\ref{th3-local},
we have that $i=n-m'-m$, where $m'$ is the sum of the multiplicities of all
the roots of $P$ greater than $c$, 
${\operatorname{val}} p^{(c)}\geq m'=n-m-i$ and $d=\deg p^{(c)}\leq m'+m=n-i$.
Moreover, since  either $i=0$ or $c_{i}<c_{i+1}$,
we get, by Point~\eqref{th3-2}, that $p_{n-i}\neq 0$, hence $\deg p^{(c)}=n-i$.
Similarly, we have either $i+m=n$ or $c_{i+m}<c_{i+m+1}$.
In the second case, we get $p_{n-i-m}\neq 0$, thus ${\operatorname{val}} p^{(c)}=n-m-i$.
In the first case, $n-m-i=0$ and either $p_{0}\neq  0$ or $P_{0}={\mathbbold{0}}$.
Since $P_{0}={\mathbbold{0}}$ implies $c=c_n={\mathbbold{0}}$, which contradicts our
assumption, we must have $p_0\neq 0$, hence again ${\operatorname{val}} p^{(c)}=n-m-i$.
This shows that $\deg p^{(c)}-{\operatorname{val}} p^{(c)}=m$, so that
$ p^{(c)}$ has $\ell=m$ non-zero roots and applying 
Theorem~\ref{th3-local}, we get that
if $y_{i+1},\ldots, y_{i+m}$ denote its non-zero roots,
then there exist $m$ roots
of ${\mathcal{P}}$  (counted with multiplicities),
 ${\mathcal{Y}}_{i+1},\ldots, {\mathcal{Y}}_{i+m}\in {\mathcal{C}}$,
 having first order asymptotics of the form
${\mathcal{Y}}_j\sim y_j {\epsilon}^c$, $i+1\leq j\leq i+m$.

Finally, if $c={\mathbbold{0}}$ is a root of $P$ with multiplicity $m$, then 
$c_{n-m}<c_{n-m+1}=\cdots =c_n={\mathbbold{0}}$, ${\operatorname{val}} P=m$, and
$P$ has $n-m$ roots $\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$.
This implies that ${\operatorname{val}} {\mathcal{P}}\geq m$, so that $0$ is
a root of ${\mathcal{P}}$ with multiplicity $\geq m$.
Moreover, we have shown above that there exist $n-m$ roots of ${\mathcal{P}}$ with first
order asymptotics with respective 
exponents $c_1\leq \cdots \leq c_{n-m}<+\infty$.
Hence, ${\mathcal{P}}$ cannot have more than $m$ zero roots, so that ${\mathcal{P}}$  has exactly
$m$ roots with first order asymptotics of the form $Y_j\sim 0$
(and ${\operatorname{val}} {\mathcal{P}}= m$).
We thus have shown Point~\eqref{th3-1}, which finishes the proof of the theorem.
\end{proof}

${\widehat{{A}}}(y):= A_0\oplus y A_1 \oplus \cdots  \oplus y^dA_d\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$.
We call {\em {min-plus characteristic polynomial}}\index{{min-plus characteristic polynomial}} of the matrix polynomial $A$,
the permanent \(
P_A = {\operatorname{per}} A\). This is a formal polynomial, the  associated
polynomial function of which is equal to
\( {\widehat{{P_A}}}(y) = {\operatorname{per}} {\widehat{{A}}}(y)\).

We shall say that the matrix polynomial $A$ is {\em regular} if $P_A$ is
not identically zero. 


Then, the min-plus roots of $P_A$ will be called the
{\em algebraic eigenvalues} of the min-plus matrix polynomial $A$. 
Note that the valuation ${\operatorname{val}} P_A$ can be computed
by introducing the matrix ${\operatorname{val}} A\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$,
such that $({\operatorname{val}} A)_{ij}={\operatorname{val}} A_{ij}$,
where $A_{ij}$ denotes the $(i,j)$ entry of the min-plus polynomial $A$.
Then, ${\operatorname{val}} P_A$ is equal to the min-plus permanent of the matrix ${\operatorname{val}} A$.
By symmetry, the degree $\deg P_A$ is equal to the 
max-plus permanent of the matrix
$\deg A \in {\mathbb{R}}_{\max}^{n\times n}$,
such that $(\deg A)_{ij}=\deg A_{ij}$.
When  ${\operatorname{val}} P_A>0$, ${\mathbbold{0}}=+\infty$ is an eigenvalue of $A$
with multiplicity ${\operatorname{val}} P_A$. When $\deg P_A<nd $, 
$P_A$ has only $\deg P_A$ eigenvalues (belonging to ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$).
One can say that $-\infty$ (the
infinity of ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$) is an eigenvalue of $A$ with multiplicity 
$nd- \deg P_A$.
Recall that, for any scalar $y\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$,
we have  \( {\widehat{{P_A}}}(y) = {\operatorname{per}} {\widehat{{A}}}(y)\)
which is the value of the optimal assignment associated to the
matrix ${\widehat{{A}}}(y)$.

Hook~\cite{James} showed that this can be reduced to a $O(n^3d^2)$ time.

\begin{theorem}
\label{th-1-gen}
Let ${\mathcal{A}}$ be a matrix polynomial over ${\mathcal{C}}$
as in~\eqref{defAepsilon} satisfying~\eqref{pencil-asymp}
and denote by $A$ the min-plus matrix polynomial~\eqref{defAtrop}
with coefficients $A_k$ as in~\eqref{pencil-asymp}.
Assume that $A$ is a regular matrix polynomial.
Then, for generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$,
the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular,
the inequalities in Theorem~\ref{th-1} are equalities,
and all eigenvalues of the matrix po lynomial ${\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon$ have
first order asymptotics. More precisely,
we have:
\begin{enumerate}
\item ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}= {\operatorname{val}} P_A$, which means that
${\mathbbold{0}}=+\infty$ is an eigenvalue of $A$ if and only if
$0$ is an eigenvalue of ${\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon$ and they have same multiplicity.
\item $\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}= \deg P_A$, which means that
$-\infty$ is an eigenvalue of $A$ if and only if
$\infty$ is an eigenvalue of ${\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon$ and they have same multiplicity.
\item for any finite ($\neq\pm\infty$) algebraic eigenvalue  $\gamma$ of $A$,
the matrix polynomial $a^{(\gamma)}$ of~\eqref{pencilsat} is regular, and
has $m_{\gamma,A}$ non-zero eigenvalues. Moreover, 
$m'_{\gamma,A}={\operatorname{val}} \det (a^{(\gamma)})$ is the the multiplicity of
$0$ as an eigenvalue of the matrix polynomial $a^{(\gamma)}$,
and  $m''_{\gamma,A}=nd-m_{\gamma,A}-m'_{\gamma,A}$ is the multiplicity of 
$\infty$  as an eigenvalue of the matrix polynomial $a^{(\gamma)}$,
as it were of degree $d$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
Let us denote by ${\mathcal{Q}}=\det({{\mathcal{A}}})\in{\mathcal{C}}[{\mathsf{Y}}]$ 
the characteristic polynomial of ${\mathcal{A}}$ 
and by $P={\operatorname{per}} A$ the min-plus characteristic polynomial of $A$.
Since ${\mathcal{A}}_d=I$, we have ${\mathcal{Q}}_{nd}=1$ and $P_{nd}={\mathbbold{1}}$.
The eigenvalues ${\mathcal{L}}^1_{\epsilon},\ldots , {\mathcal{L}}^{nd}_{\epsilon}$
of ${\mathcal{A}}_{\epsilon}$ are the roots of the polynomial ${\mathcal{Q}}$.
Assume that they  have first order asymptotics with exponents
$\Lambda_1\leq \cdots \leq \Lambda_{nd}$.
From~\eqref{puis0}, these are elements of ${\mathcal{C}}{^\dag}$
and their images by ${\mathsf{e}}$ (counted with multiplicities)
are equal to $\Lambda_1\leq \cdots \leq \Lambda_{nd}$.
By Proposition~\ref{prop-kap-pre} applied to the ring ${\mathcal{C}}$,
$\Lambda=(\Lambda_1\leq \cdots \leq \Lambda_{nd})$
coincide with the roots of the min-plus polynomial $Q={\mathsf{e}({{\mathcal{Q}}})}$.
Then, computing the coefficients of the formal polynomial ${\mathcal{Q}}$,
we can deduce that $Q\geq P$. Since $Q_{nd}=P_{nd}={\mathbbold{1}}$,
we get that $\Lambda=R(Q){\prec^{\rm w}} R(P)=\Gamma$.

Note that another way to prove this result is to apply a block companion 
transformation to the matrix polynomials ${\mathcal{A}}$ and $A$,
yielding linear pencils ${\mathcal{B}}$ and $B$ with leading terms
${\mathcal{B}}_1$ and $B_1$ equal to the
identity matrix, then to apply Theorem~\ref{th-major-cont} to 
${\mathcal{B}}_0$.
\end{proof}

For any matrix $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$,
we define the graph ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ as the set of arcs belonging
to optimal assignments: the set of nodes of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ 
is $[n]$ and there is an arc from $i$ to
$j$ if there is a permutation $\sigma$ such that
$j=\sigma(i)$ and $|\sigma|_B={\operatorname{per}} B$.
One can compute ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ by  using the following construction.

We shall say that two vectors
$U,V$ of dimension $n$ with entries in ${\mathbb{R}}={\mathbb{R}}_{\min}\setminus\{{\mathbbold{0}}\}$
form a {\em {Hungarian pair}}\index{{Hungarian pair}} with respect to $B$ if, for all $i,j$,
we have $B_{ij}\geq U_iV_j$, 
and $U_1\cdots U_n V_1\cdots V_n={\operatorname{per}} B$,
the products being understood
in the min-plus sense (since $U,V$ are seen as elements of ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^n$).
Thus, $(U,V)$ coincides with the
optimal dual variable in the linear programming
formulation of the optimal assignment problem.
In particular, a Hungarian pair always exists if
the optimal assignment problem is feasible,
i.e., if ${\operatorname{per}} B \neq {\mathbbold{0}}$, and it can
be computed in $O(n^3)$ time by the Hungarian
algorithm (see for instance~\cite[\S~17]{schrijver}).
For any Hungarian pair $(U,V)$, we now define 
the {\em saturation graph}, 
${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$, which has set of nodes $[n]$
and an arc from $i$ to $j$ if $B_{ij}=U_iV_{j}$.
We shall see in the following section that ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ can be 
computed easily from ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.

For any min-plus matrix polynomial $A$ and any
scalar $\gamma\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$, we denote by ${\mathcal{G}}_k(A,\gamma)$ the graph
with set of nodes $[n]$, and an arc from $i$ to
$j\in [n]$ if $\gamma^k(A_k)_{ij}={\widehat{{A}}}_{ij}(\gamma)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$.
This is a subgraph of the graph of ${\widehat{{A}}}(\gamma)$.









For any graphs $G$ and $G'$, the {\em intersection} $G\cap G'$ is
the graph whose set of nodes (resp.\ arcs) is the
intersection of the sets of nodes (resp.\ arcs) of $G$ and $G'$.
Finally, if $G$ is any graph with set of nodes $[n]$, 
and if $b\in {\mathbb{C}}^{n\times n}$,
we define the matrix $b^{G}$ by
$(b^{G})_{ij}=b_{ij}$ if $(i,j)\in G$,
and $(b^{G})_{ij}=0$ otherwise.

\begin{corollary}\label{coro2}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ be such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$,
and let $(U,V)$ be a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$.
Then, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)\subset{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.
Moreover, the following are equivalent for $\sigma\in {\mathfrak{S}}_n$:
(i) $\sigma$ is a permutation of  ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$; (ii)
$\sigma$ is a permutation of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$; (iii) $\sigma$
is an optimal permutation of $B$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
Let $C$ be as in Corollary~\ref{coro1}.
Then, if $(i,j)$ is an arc of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)$,
there exists $\sigma\in{\mathfrak{S}}_n$ such that
$j=\sigma(i)$ and $|\sigma|_C={\operatorname{per}} C={\mathbbold{1}}$.
Since all entries of $C$ are greater or equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, 
this implies that $C_{ij}={\mathbbold{1}}$, and so
$(i,j)$ is an arc of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$.
Since ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ and ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$,
this shows that ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)\subset{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.

Let us show that for $\sigma\in {\mathfrak{S}}_n$, (i)$\Rightarrow$(iii)$\Rightarrow$(ii)$\Rightarrow$(i).
Let $\sigma$ be a permutation of  ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$, this means that
$(i,\sigma(i))$ is an arc of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$, for all $i \in [n]$.
Then  $C_{i\sigma(i)}={\mathbbold{1}}$, for all  $i \in [n]$, which implies that
 $|\sigma|_C={\mathbbold{1}}={\operatorname{per}} C$, and so $\sigma$ is an optimal permutation 
of $C$, hence an optimal permutation of $B$, by Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation},
which shows (i)$\Rightarrow$(iii).
By definition of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, if $\sigma$ be an optimal permutation of $B$,
then $(i,\sigma(i))$ is an arc of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, for all $i\in [n]$,
so $\sigma$ is a permutation of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, which shows (iii)$\Rightarrow$(ii).
If now $\sigma$ be a permutation of  ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, then, for all $i\in [n]$,
$(i,\sigma(i))$ is an arc of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)\subset {{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$,  hence, 
$\sigma$ is a permutation of  ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$, which shows (ii)$\Rightarrow$(i).
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{coro3}

let $\sigma$ be an optimal permutation for $B$,
and let $(U,V)$ be  a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$.
Then,  the identity map is an optimal permutation for 
${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$ and
 $(U_{\sigma^{-1}},V)$ is  a Hungarian pair with respect to ${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$.
Moreover, we have ${\operatorname{per}} ({P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B)={\operatorname{per}} (B)$,
${\text{\rm {Opt}}}({P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B)={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$,
and ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}({P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B,U_{\sigma^{-1}},V)={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
From Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation},
$\nu$ is an optimal permutation for ${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$ if and only if
$\nu\circ \sigma$ is an optimal permutation for $B$.
Hence if $\sigma$ is an optimal permutation for $B$,
 the identity map is an optimal permutation for ${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$.
The other properties follow from Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation}.
\end{proof}

$({\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$ is a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$ and
the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$.
Then $B{\mathbbold{1}} ={\mathbbold{1}}$, ${\rho_{\min}}(B)={\mathbbold{1}}$, and ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$
is the critical graph of $B$.



\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let $B$ be as in the proposition.
Since $({\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$ is a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$,
Corollary~\ref{coro1} shows that
all entries of $B$ are greater or equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, and
that $B_{ij}={\mathbbold{1}}$ for all arcs $(i,j)$ of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$.
Then, by Corollary~\ref{coro2}, $B_{ij}={\mathbbold{1}}$ for all arcs $(i,j)$ of 
an optimal permutation of $B$.
Since the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$,
this implies that $B_{ii}={\mathbbold{1}}$ for all $i$,
which implies $B{\mathbbold{1}}={\mathbbold{1}}$.
Moreover, all circuits have a weight with respect to $B$ greater or equal
to ${\mathbbold{1}}$ and the circuits of an optimal permutation
have a weight equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$. This implies that ${\rho_{\min}}(B)={\mathbbold{1}}$.

Let  $(i,j)$ be an arc of the critical graph of $B$.
By definition (see Section~\ref{sec-tropeig}),
there exists a circuit passing through $(i,j)$ 
with mean weight with respect to $B$ equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, 
so with weight equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$.
Since the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$,
any circuit  with weight ${\mathbbold{1}}$ can be completed into a permutation 
with weight ${\mathbbold{1}}$, by taking the identity on the complementary of this 
circuit, hence, $(i,j)$ is an arc of  ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$.
Conversely, let  $(i,j)$ be an arc of  ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, then there exists
an optimal permutation $\sigma$ for $B$ such that $j=\sigma(i)$.
This implies (as above) that $B_{k\sigma(k)}={\mathbbold{1}}$, for all $k\in [n]$.
Then, all the circuits of $\sigma$ have a weight equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$,
and so are critical circuits. Since $(i,j)$ belongs to one of them, this shows
that $(i,j)$ is an arc of the critical graph of $B$.
















\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{coro4}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ be as in Proposition~\ref{prop-carac-hungarian}. 
Then, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ is the disjoint union of the strongly connected components
of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
By Proposition~\ref{prop-carac-hungarian}, ${\mathbbold{1}}$ is a fixed point 
of $B$, and ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ is the critical graph of $B$.
It is known that the critical graph of $B$ is
the disjoint union of the strongly connected components of
the saturation graph of $B$ on any eigenvector $U$ of $B$, that is the
set of arcs $(i,j)$ such that $B_{ij} U_j=U_i$
(see for instance~\cite{abg04b}).
When $U={\mathbbold{1}}$, this saturation graph coincides with ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$,
which shows the corollary.
Let us reproduce the proof in that case.
Indeed, let $(i,j)$ be an arc of a strongly connected component of
the saturation graph of $B$ on the eigenvector ${\mathbbold{1}}$. Then there exists
a path from $j$ to $i$ in this saturation graph.
Concatenating this path with the arc $(i,j)$, we get a circuit,
the weights with respect to $B$ of which are all equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, hence a 
critical circuit of $B$. This shows that $(i,j)$ is an arc of the critical graph
of $B$. Since the critical graph of $B$ is the
union of its strongly connected components, and is always included
in the saturation graph, we get the desired property.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{coro5}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$,
$(U,V)$ be a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$,
and suppose that the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$.
Then, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ is the disjoint union of the strongly connected components
of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
Corollary~\ref{coro1} shows that the matrix $C$ defined there satisfies
${\operatorname{per}} C={\mathbbold{1}}$, that
$({\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$ is a Hungarian pair with respect to $C$, together with
${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)$ and ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$.
Moreover, by Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation}, the optimal
permutations for $B$ and $C$ coincide, so that 
the identity map is an optimal permutation of $C$.
Hence, $C$ satisfies the assumptions of Proposition~\ref{prop-carac-hungarian},
so that, by Corollary~\ref{coro4}, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)$ 
is the disjoint union of the strongly connected components
of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$. With the above equalities, 
this shows the corollary.
\end{proof}

The above results show that ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ can be easily be constructed from
any Hungarian pair with respect to $B$, as follows.

\begin{corollary}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$.
Let $(U,V)$ be a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$,
and $\sigma$ be a permutation of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.
Then, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$ is the disjoint union of the 
strongly connected components of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$.
\end{corollary}

\section{Proof of Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}}

We prove here the different assertions in
Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}.

Since the intersection of generic sets is a generic set, 
it suffices to prove separately
that each point of Theorem~\ref{th-1-gen} 
holds for generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$.

Let us introduce some additional notation.
For any $n\geq 1$ and $d\geq 0$,
the characteristic polynomial  $\det(a)$ of the
matrix polynomial $a=a_0+{\mathsf{Y}} a_1+\cdots+{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$ with coefficients
in ${\mathbb{C}}^{n\times n}$ can be thought of as a (formal) complex 
polynomial, denoted ${\operatorname{ch}}$, in the variables
${\mathsf{Y}}$ and $(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
the coefficients of which are integers.
Hence, the coefficient ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell$, $0\leq \ell\leq nd$,
of ${\mathsf{Y}}^\ell$ in ${\operatorname{ch}}$ can be thought of as a (formal) complex 
polynomial in the variables
$(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$.
In the sequel, we shall write $p(a)$ 
when $p$ is a polynomial in the
variables $(a_k)_{ij}\in{\mathbb{C}}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
and  $a=a_0+{\mathsf{Y}} a_1+\cdots+{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$.
We have in particular ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell(a_0+{\mathsf{Y}} I)={\operatorname{tr}}_{n-\ell}(a_0)$.
Similarly, the characteristic polynomial  ${\operatorname{per}} a$ of the min-plus
(formal) matrix polynomial $a=a_0\oplus{\mathsf{Y}} a_1\oplus\cdots\oplus{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$,
with coefficients in ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ can be thought of as a (formal) min-plus
 polynomial, denoted  ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}$, in the variables
${\mathsf{Y}}$ and $(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
the coefficients of which are all equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, and 
the coefficient ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell$, $0\leq \ell\leq nd$,
of ${\mathsf{Y}}^\ell$ in ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}$ can be thought of as a (formal) min-plus
polynomial in the variables
$(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$.
Again, we shall write  $p(a)$ instead of $p$, 
when  $p$ is a min-plus formal polynomial in the
variables $(a_k)_{ij}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
and $a=a_0\oplus{\mathsf{Y}} a_1\oplus\cdots\oplus{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$.
We shall also use the notation ${\widehat{{p}}}(a)$  for the associated 
polynomial function.
We have in particular ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell(a_0\oplus{\mathsf{Y}} I)={\operatorname{tr}}^{\min}_{n-\ell}(a_0)$,
where ${\operatorname{tr}}^{\min}_k$ is the min-plus (formal) $k$-th trace given by
the formula~\eqref{trmin}.
In the sequel, ${\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}$ will denote the polynomial function associated
to the formal polynomial  ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell$.


In all the proofs of the present section,
we consider a matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}$ over ${\mathcal{C}}$
as in~\eqref{defAepsilon} satisfying~\eqref{pencil-asymp}
and denote by $A$ the min-plus matrix polynomial~\eqref{defAtrop}
with coefficients $A_k$ as in~\eqref{pencil-asymp}.


\subsection{Proof of the first properties in
Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}}
Let us prove the  following implications which correspond to the
first properties stated in Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}.
\begin{enumerate}
\item\label{impl1} If ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular, then so does $A$.
\item\label{impl2} If $A$ is regular, then 
for generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$,
the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular.
\end{enumerate}
From the above notations, 
it is easy to see that the min-plus polynomial ${\mathsf{e}({{\operatorname{ch}}})}$ 
(defined as in~\eqref{qQ}) is equal to ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}$ and
that ${\mathsf{e}({{\operatorname{ch}}_\ell})}={\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell$.
Then, by Lemma~\ref{gener}, we obtain that for $a$, $A$ and ${\mathcal{A}}$ as
above,
we have  ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\simeq ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{{\eval{{\operatorname{ch}}}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)}$.
Moreover,  by Lemma~\ref{gener} again, 
for any fixed $A$ such that ${\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$,
we have $({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a)\neq 0$
for generic values of $a$ (so of the $(a_k)_{ij}$),
hence the equivalence  ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\sim ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{{\eval{{\operatorname{ch}}}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)}$.

Using these properties, we  see that if $A$ is singular,
then ${\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)={\mathbbold{0}}$ for all $\ell\geq 0$, hence
${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\simeq ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{+\infty}$ and so ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})=0$,
which implies that $\det({\mathcal{A}})={\operatorname{ch}}({\mathcal{A}})=0$ and so ${\mathcal{A}}$ is singular.
Conversely, if $A$ is regular, then there exists $\ell\geq 0$ 
(for instance the degree of ${\operatorname{per}} A$) such that
$\alpha={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$, and since for generic values of $a$,
$({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a)\neq 0$, 
and ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\sim ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{\alpha}$,
we get that ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\neq 0$.
Hence, $\det({\mathcal{A}})={\operatorname{ch}}({\mathcal{A}})$ is non identically zero, 
so the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular for generic values of $a$.

\subsection{Proof of Points~\eqref{th-1-val} and~\eqref{th-1-deg}  of
 Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}}

Assume first that ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular as in Theorem~\ref{th-1}.
By the property~\ref{impl1}  already proved in the previous section,
$A$ is also regular. Then, $P_A={\operatorname{per}} A$ and $P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}=\det ({\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon)$ 
have finite valuations and degree,
such that $0\leq {\operatorname{val}} P_A\leq \deg P_A\leq nd$
and $0\leq {\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq nd$.
The inequalities ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\geq {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and 
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_A$ are trivial when ${\operatorname{val}} P_A=0$ and
$\deg P_A=nd$.
When ${\operatorname{val}} P_A>0$, 
${\mathbbold{0}}$ is an eigenvalue of $A$ with multiplicity $m_{{\mathbbold{0}},A}={\operatorname{val}} P_A$,
and $(P_A)_{\ell}={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)={\mathbbold{0}}$, for $\ell<{\operatorname{val}} P_A$.
Then, by the same arguments as in the previous section,
we have ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})=0$, for $\ell<{\operatorname{val}} P_A$,
hence, for all ${\epsilon}>0$,  ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\geq {\operatorname{val}} P_A$, and 
$0$ is an eigenvalue of ${\mathcal{A}}_{\epsilon}$ with multiplicity $\geq m_{{\mathbbold{0}},A}$.
Similarly, when $\deg P_A<nd$, $-\infty$ is an 
eigenvalue of $A$ with multiplicity $m_{-\infty,A}=nd-d_A$,
and $(P_A)_{\ell}={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)={\mathbbold{0}}$, for $\ell>\deg P_A$.
Then, by the same arguments as in the previous section,
we have ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})=0$, for $\ell>\deg P_A$,
hence  $\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_A$,
and $\infty$ is an eigenvalue of ${\mathcal{A}}_{\epsilon}$ with multiplicity $\geq m_{-\infty,A}$.
This proves Points~\eqref{th-1-val} and~\eqref{th-1-deg}  of 
 Theorem~\ref{th-1}.


Assume now that $A$ is regular as in Theorem~\ref{th-1-gen}.
By the property~\ref{impl2}  already proved in the previous section,
${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular, for generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$.
Then, by what is already proved above, for
these generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$,
the inequalities ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\geq {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and 
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_A$ hold.
By the definition of the valuation and degree, we have
$(P_A)_{\ell}={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$, for
$\ell= {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and $\ell=\deg P_A$.
Moreover, using Lemma~\ref{gener}, for both values of $\ell$, we have 
${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\simeq ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{{\eval{{\operatorname{ch}}}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)}$,
and for generic values of $a$, we have $({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a)\neq 0$,
and  ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\sim ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{\alpha}$,
so ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\neq 0$.
Hence,  for these generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$,
we have  ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}= {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and 
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}=\deg P_A$.
Since the intersection of generic sets is a generic set, 
all the above properties hold for generic values of $a$:
${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular, ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}= {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and  
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}=\deg P_A$.

Then  $C_{i\sigma(i)}={\mathbbold{1}}$, for all  $i \in [n]$, which implies that
 $|\sigma|_C={\mathbbold{1}}={\operatorname{per}} C$, and so $\sigma$ is an optimal permutation 
of $C$, hence an optimal permutation of $B$, by Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation},
which shows (i)$\Rightarrow$(iii).
By definition of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, if $\sigma$ be an optimal permutation of $B$,
then $(i,\sigma(i))$ is an arc of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, for all $i\in [n]$,
so $\sigma$ is a permutation of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, which shows (iii)$\Rightarrow$(ii).
If now $\sigma$ be a permutation of  ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, then, for all $i\in [n]$,
$(i,\sigma(i))$ is an arc of ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)\subset {{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$,  hence, 
$\sigma$ is a permutation of  ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$, which shows (ii)$\Rightarrow$(i).
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{coro3}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$,
let $\sigma$ be an optimal permutation for $B$,
and let $(U,V)$ be  a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$.
Then,  the identity map is an optimal permutation for 
${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$ and
 $(U_{\sigma^{-1}},V)$ is  a Hungarian pair with respect to ${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$.
Moreover, we have ${\operatorname{per}} ({P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B)={\operatorname{per}} (B)$,
${\text{\rm {Opt}}}({P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B)={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$,
and ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}({P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B,U_{\sigma^{-1}},V)={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
From Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation},
$\nu$ is an optimal permutation for ${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$ if and only if
$\nu\circ \sigma$ is an optimal permutation for $B$.
Hence if $\sigma$ is an optimal permutation for $B$,
 the identity map is an optimal permutation for ${P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$.
The other properties follow from Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation}.
\end{proof}















\begin{proposition}\label{prop-carac-hungarian}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ such that ${\operatorname{per}} B={\mathbbold{1}}$,
$({\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$ is a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$ and
the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$.
Then $B{\mathbbold{1}} ={\mathbbold{1}}$, ${\rho_{\min}}(B)={\mathbbold{1}}$, and ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$
is the critical graph of $B$.



\end{proposition}
\begin{proof}
Let $B$ be as in the proposition.
Since $({\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$ is a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$,
Corollary~\ref{coro1} shows that
all entries of $B$ are greater or equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, and
that $B_{ij}={\mathbbold{1}}$ for all arcs $(i,j)$ of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$.
Then, by Corollary~\ref{coro2}, $B_{ij}={\mathbbold{1}}$ for all arcs $(i,j)$ of 
an optimal permutation of $B$.
Since the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$,
this implies that $B_{ii}={\mathbbold{1}}$ for all $i$,
which implies $B{\mathbbold{1}}={\mathbbold{1}}$.
Moreover, all circuits have a weight with respect to $B$ greater or equal
to ${\mathbbold{1}}$ and the circuits of an optimal permutation
have a weight equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$. This implies that ${\rho_{\min}}(B)={\mathbbold{1}}$.

Let  $(i,j)$ be an arc of the critical graph of $B$.
By definition (see Section~\ref{sec-tropeig}),
there exists a circuit passing through $(i,j)$ 
with mean weight with respect to $B$ equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, 
so with weight equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$.
Since the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$,
any circuit  with weight ${\mathbbold{1}}$ can be completed into a permutation 
with weight ${\mathbbold{1}}$, by taking the identity on the complementary of this 
circuit, hence, $(i,j)$ is an arc of  ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$.
Conversely, let  $(i,j)$ be an arc of  ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$, then there exists
an optimal permutation $\sigma$ for $B$ such that $j=\sigma(i)$.
This implies (as above) that $B_{k\sigma(k)}={\mathbbold{1}}$, for all $k\in [n]$.
Then, all the circuits of $\sigma$ have a weight equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$,
and so are critical circuits. Since $(i,j)$ belongs to one of them, this shows
that $(i,j)$ is an arc of the critical graph of $B$.
















\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{coro4}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ be as in Proposition~\ref{prop-carac-hungarian}. 
Then, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ is the disjoint union of the strongly connected components
of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
By Proposition~\ref{prop-carac-hungarian}, ${\mathbbold{1}}$ is a fixed point 
of $B$, and ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ is the critical graph of $B$.
It is known that the critical graph of $B$ is
the disjoint union of the strongly connected components of
the saturation graph of $B$ on any eigenvector $U$ of $B$, that is the
set of arcs $(i,j)$ such that $B_{ij} U_j=U_i$
(see for instance~\cite{abg04b}).
When $U={\mathbbold{1}}$, this saturation graph coincides with ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$,
which shows the corollary.
Let us reproduce the proof in that case.
Indeed, let $(i,j)$ be an arc of a strongly connected component of
the saturation graph of $B$ on the eigenvector ${\mathbbold{1}}$. Then there exists
a path from $j$ to $i$ in this saturation graph.
Concatenating this path with the arc $(i,j)$, we get a circuit,
the weights with respect to $B$ of which are all equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, hence a 
critical circuit of $B$. This shows that $(i,j)$ is an arc of the critical graph
of $B$. Since the critical graph of $B$ is the
union of its strongly connected components, and is always included
in the saturation graph, we get the desired property.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}\label{coro5}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$,
$(U,V)$ be a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$,
and suppose that the identity map is an optimal permutation of $B$.
Then, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ is the disjoint union of the strongly connected components
of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
Corollary~\ref{coro1} shows that the matrix $C$ defined there satisfies
${\operatorname{per}} C={\mathbbold{1}}$, that
$({\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$ is a Hungarian pair with respect to $C$, together with
${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)$ and ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$.
Moreover, by Lemma~\ref{lem-permutation}, the optimal
permutations for $B$ and $C$ coincide, so that 
the identity map is an optimal permutation of $C$.
Hence, $C$ satisfies the assumptions of Proposition~\ref{prop-carac-hungarian},
so that, by Corollary~\ref{coro4}, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)$ 
is the disjoint union of the strongly connected components
of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,{\mathbbold{1}},{\mathbbold{1}})$. With the above equalities, 
this shows the corollary.
\end{proof}

The above results show that ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ can be easily be constructed from
any Hungarian pair with respect to $B$, as follows.

\begin{corollary}
Let $B\in {\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$.
Let $(U,V)$ be a Hungarian pair with respect to $B$,
and $\sigma$ be a permutation of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.
Then, ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$ is the disjoint union of the 
strongly connected components of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$.
\end{corollary}

\section{Proof of Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}}

We prove here the different assertions in
Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}.

Since the intersection of generic sets is a generic set, 
it suffices to prove separately
that each point of Theorem~\ref{th-1-gen} 
holds for generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$.

Let us introduce some additional notation.
For any $n\geq 1$ and $d\geq 0$,
the characteristic polynomial  $\det(a)$ of the
matrix polynomial $a=a_0+{\mathsf{Y}} a_1+\cdots+{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$ with coefficients
in ${\mathbb{C}}^{n\times n}$ can be thought of as a (formal) complex 
polynomial, denoted ${\operatorname{ch}}$, in the variables
${\mathsf{Y}}$ and $(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
the coefficients of which are integers.
Hence, the coefficient ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell$, $0\leq \ell\leq nd$,
of ${\mathsf{Y}}^\ell$ in ${\operatorname{ch}}$ can be thought of as a (formal) complex 
polynomial in the variables
$(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$.
In the sequel, we shall write $p(a)$ 
when $p$ is a polynomial in the
variables $(a_k)_{ij}\in{\mathbb{C}}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
and  $a=a_0+{\mathsf{Y}} a_1+\cdots+{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$.
We have in particular ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell(a_0+{\mathsf{Y}} I)={\operatorname{tr}}_{n-\ell}(a_0)$.
Similarly, the characteristic polynomial  ${\operatorname{per}} a$ of the min-plus
(formal) matrix polynomial $a=a_0\oplus{\mathsf{Y}} a_1\oplus\cdots\oplus{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$,
with coefficients in ${\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ can be thought of as a (formal) min-plus
 polynomial, denoted  ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}$, in the variables
${\mathsf{Y}}$ and $(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
the coefficients of which are all equal to ${\mathbbold{1}}$, and 
the coefficient ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell$, $0\leq \ell\leq nd$,
of ${\mathsf{Y}}^\ell$ in ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}$ can be thought of as a (formal) min-plus
polynomial in the variables
$(a_k)_{ij}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$.
Again, we shall write  $p(a)$ instead of $p$, 
when  $p$ is a min-plus formal polynomial in the
variables $(a_k)_{ij}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\min}$ with $k=0,\ldots, d$ and $i,j=1,\ldots , n$,
and $a=a_0\oplus{\mathsf{Y}} a_1\oplus\cdots\oplus{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d$.
We shall also use the notation ${\widehat{{p}}}(a)$  for the associated 
polynomial function.
We have in particular ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell(a_0\oplus{\mathsf{Y}} I)={\operatorname{tr}}^{\min}_{n-\ell}(a_0)$,
where ${\operatorname{tr}}^{\min}_k$ is the min-plus (formal) $k$-th trace given by
the formula~\eqref{trmin}.
In the sequel, ${\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}$ will denote the polynomial function associated
to the formal polynomial  ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell$.


In all the proofs of the present section,
we consider a matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}$ over ${\mathcal{C}}$
as in~\eqref{defAepsilon} satisfying~\eqref{pencil-asymp}
and denote by $A$ the min-plus matrix polynomial~\eqref{defAtrop}
with coefficients $A_k$ as in~\eqref{pencil-asymp}.


\subsection{Proof of the first properties in
Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}}
Let us prove the  following implications which correspond to the
first properties stated in Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}.
\begin{enumerate}
\item\label{impl1} If ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular, then so does $A$.
\item\label{impl2} If $A$ is regular, then 
for generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$,
the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular.
\end{enumerate}
From the above notations, 
it is easy to see that the min-plus polynomial ${\mathsf{e}({{\operatorname{ch}}})}$ 
(defined as in~\eqref{qQ}) is equal to ${\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}$ and
that ${\mathsf{e}({{\operatorname{ch}}_\ell})}={\operatorname{ch}}^{\min}_\ell$.
Then, by Lemma~\ref{gener}, we obtain that for $a$, $A$ and ${\mathcal{A}}$ as
above,
we have  ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\simeq ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{{\eval{{\operatorname{ch}}}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)}$.
Moreover,  by Lemma~\ref{gener} again, 
for any fixed $A$ such that ${\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$,
we have $({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a)\neq 0$
for generic values of $a$ (so of the $(a_k)_{ij}$),
hence the equivalence  ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\sim ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{{\eval{{\operatorname{ch}}}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)}$.

Using these properties, we  see that if $A$ is singular,
then ${\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)={\mathbbold{0}}$ for all $\ell\geq 0$, hence
${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\simeq ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{+\infty}$ and so ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})=0$,
which implies that $\det({\mathcal{A}})={\operatorname{ch}}({\mathcal{A}})=0$ and so ${\mathcal{A}}$ is singular.
Conversely, if $A$ is regular, then there exists $\ell\geq 0$ 
(for instance the degree of ${\operatorname{per}} A$) such that
$\alpha={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$, and since for generic values of $a$,
$({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a)\neq 0$, 
and ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\sim ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{\alpha}$,
we get that ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\neq 0$.
Hence, $\det({\mathcal{A}})={\operatorname{ch}}({\mathcal{A}})$ is non identically zero, 
so the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular for generic values of $a$.

\subsection{Proof of Points~\eqref{th-1-val} and~\eqref{th-1-deg}  of
 Theorems~\ref{th-1} and~\ref{th-1-gen}}

Assume first that ${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular as in Theorem~\ref{th-1}.
By the property~\ref{impl1}  already proved in the previous section,
$A$ is also regular. Then, $P_A={\operatorname{per}} A$ and $P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}=\det ({\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon)$ 
have finite valuations and degree,
such that $0\leq {\operatorname{val}} P_A\leq \deg P_A\leq nd$
and $0\leq {\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq nd$.
The inequalities ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\geq {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and 
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_A$ are trivial when ${\operatorname{val}} P_A=0$ and
$\deg P_A=nd$.
When ${\operatorname{val}} P_A>0$, 
${\mathbbold{0}}$ is an eigenvalue of $A$ with multiplicity $m_{{\mathbbold{0}},A}={\operatorname{val}} P_A$,
and $(P_A)_{\ell}={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)={\mathbbold{0}}$, for $\ell<{\operatorname{val}} P_A$.
Then, by the same arguments as in the previous section,
we have ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})=0$, for $\ell<{\operatorname{val}} P_A$,
hence, for all ${\epsilon}>0$,  ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\geq {\operatorname{val}} P_A$, and 
$0$ is an eigenvalue of ${\mathcal{A}}_{\epsilon}$ with multiplicity $\geq m_{{\mathbbold{0}},A}$.
Similarly, when $\deg P_A<nd$, $-\infty$ is an 
eigenvalue of $A$ with multiplicity $m_{-\infty,A}=nd-d_A$,
and $(P_A)_{\ell}={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)={\mathbbold{0}}$, for $\ell>\deg P_A$.
Then, by the same arguments as in the previous section,
we have ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})=0$, for $\ell>\deg P_A$,
hence  $\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_A$,
and $\infty$ is an eigenvalue of ${\mathcal{A}}_{\epsilon}$ with multiplicity $\geq m_{-\infty,A}$.
This proves Points~\eqref{th-1-val} and~\eqref{th-1-deg}  of 
 Theorem~\ref{th-1}.


Assume now that $A$ is regular as in Theorem~\ref{th-1-gen}.
By the property~\ref{impl2}  already proved in the previous section,
${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular, for generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$.
Then, by what is already proved above, for
these generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$,
the inequalities ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\geq {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and 
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}\leq \deg P_A$ hold.
By the definition of the valuation and degree, we have
$(P_A)_{\ell}={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$, for
$\ell= {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and $\ell=\deg P_A$.
Moreover, using Lemma~\ref{gener}, for both values of $\ell$, we have 
${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\simeq ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{{\eval{{\operatorname{ch}}}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(A)}$,
and for generic values of $a$, we have $({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a)\neq 0$,
and  ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\sim ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_A(a){\epsilon}^{\alpha}$,
so ${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{A}})\neq 0$.
Hence,  for these generic values of the parameters $(a_k)_{ij}$,
we have  ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}= {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and 
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}=\deg P_A$.
Since the intersection of generic sets is a generic set, 
all the above properties hold for generic values of $a$:
${\mathcal{A}}$ is regular, ${\operatorname{val}} P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}= {\operatorname{val}} P_A$ and  
$\deg P_{{\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon}=\deg P_A$.

$\det ({\mathcal{B}}_{\epsilon})=\sum_{\ell=0}^{nd}{\operatorname{ch}}_{\ell}({\mathcal{B}}_{\epsilon}){\mathsf{Y}}^\ell$
and ${\operatorname{per}} B=\oplus_{\ell=0}^{nd}{\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(B){\mathsf{Y}}^\ell$.
Moreover, by Lemma~\ref{gener},  we have
${\operatorname{ch}}_\ell({\mathcal{B}}_{\epsilon})\simeq ({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_B(a){\epsilon}^{{\eval{{\operatorname{ch}}}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(B)}$.
Hence the polynomial ${\mathcal{P}}=\det ({\mathcal{B}})\in{\mathcal{C}}[{\mathsf{Y}}]$
satisfies the assumptions of Theorem~\ref{th3-local} 
with the degree $nd$ instead of $n$, $P={\operatorname{per}} B$,
and $p=\sum_{\ell=0}^{nd}({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_B(a)$.
Moreover the scalar $c={\mathbbold{1}}$ is a finite root of $P$ with multiplicity 
$m=m_{\gamma,A}$, and we have $m'=m'_{\gamma,A}$ in Theorem~\ref{th3-local}.
Since ${\widehat{{P}}}({\mathbbold{1}})={\operatorname{per}} {\widehat{B}}({\mathbbold{1}})={\mathbbold{1}}$, we get that
$p^{({\mathbbold{1}})}=\lim_{\epsilon\to 0}\det( {\mathcal{B}}_\epsilon)$ and so the above 
properties show that $p^{({\mathbbold{1}})}= \det (a^{(\gamma)})$.

Assume now that the matrix polynomial  $a^{(\gamma)}$ is regular.
This means that  $p^{({\mathbbold{1}})}$ is non identically zero.
Applying Theorem~\ref{th3-local}, we get that if it has $m_\gamma\geq 1$
non-zero eigenvalues, $\lambda_1,\ldots,\lambda_{m_\gamma}$,
then, the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{B}}_\epsilon$ has $m_\gamma$ eigenvalues
${\mathcal{M}}_{\epsilon,1},\ldots,{\mathcal{M}}_{\epsilon,m_\gamma}$
with limits $\lambda_1,\ldots,\lambda_{m_\gamma}$. This implies that 
 ${\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon$ has $m_\gamma$ eigenvalues
${\mathcal{L}}_{\epsilon,i}=\epsilon^{\gamma} {\mathcal{M}}_{\epsilon,i}$, $i=1,\ldots,m_\gamma$,
with first order asymptotics of the form
\(
{\mathcal{L}}_{\epsilon,i}\sim \lambda_i \epsilon^{\gamma}
\).
If $0$ is an eigenvalue of the matrix polynomial $a^{(\gamma)}$
with multiplicity $m'_\gamma$, then the valuation of
$p^{({\mathbbold{1}})}$ is equal to $m'_\gamma$, hence applying Theorem~\ref{th3-local}, 
we get that the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{B}}_\epsilon$ 
has precisely $m'_\gamma$ eigenvalues converging to $0$.
Finally, the remaining $m''_\gamma=nd-m_\gamma-m'_\gamma$ 
eigenvalues of ${\mathcal{B}}_\epsilon$ have a modulus 
converging to infinity. Hence, 
the matrix polynomial ${\mathcal{A}}_\epsilon$ has precisely $m'_\gamma$
eigenvalues ${\mathcal{L}}_\epsilon$ such that
${\mathcal{L}}_{\epsilon}\simeq 0 \epsilon^{\gamma}$, and $m''_\gamma=nd-m_\gamma-m'_\gamma$ 
eigenvalues ${\mathcal{L}}_\epsilon$ 
such that the modulus of $\epsilon^{-\gamma}{\mathcal{L}}_{\epsilon}$
converges to infinity.
Finally the inequalities $m_\gamma\leq m_{\gamma,A}$,
$m'_\gamma\geq m'_{\gamma,A}$ and $m''_\gamma\geq m''_{\gamma,A}$ are deduced 
from Theorem~\ref{th3-local}.
This finishes the
proof of Point~\eqref{th-1-finite} of  Theorem~\ref{th-1} 
in the case $G={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}({\widehat{A}}(\gamma),U,V)$.

Let us show Point~\eqref{th-1-finite} of  Theorem~\ref{th-1-gen}.
Let us fix the matrix polynomial $A$ and so the matrix polynomial $B$.
By Lemma~\ref{gener},  for all $\ell$ such that 
$P_{\ell}={\eval{\ch}{}^{\min}_{{\ell}}}(B)\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$, we have that,
for generic values of $a$, $p_{\ell}=({\operatorname{ch}}_\ell)^{{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}_B(a)\neq 0$.
Since ${\mathbbold{1}}$ is a finite root of $P$ with multiplicity $m_{\gamma,A}$,
and $m'_{\gamma,A}$  is the sum of the multiplicities of all the 
roots of $P$ greater than ${\mathbbold{1}}$,
we obtain, from Corollary~\ref{carac-mul},
that $P_{\ell}={\widehat{{P}}}({\mathbbold{1}})={\mathbbold{1}}\neq {\mathbbold{0}}$ for
$\ell=m'_{\gamma,A}$ and $\ell=m'_{\gamma,A}+m_{\gamma,A}$.
Then, for generic values of $a$, we have $p_{\ell}\neq 0$
for $\ell=m'_{\gamma,A}$ and $\ell=m'_{\gamma,A}+m_{\gamma,A}$,
which implies that the polynomial
$p^{({\mathbbold{1}})}$ of~\eqref{defpc} is non zero and that its valuation is equal
to $m'_{\gamma,A}$ and its degree is equal to $m'_{\gamma,A}+m_{\gamma,A}$.
Then, for generic values of $a$,  $m_\gamma= m_{\gamma,A}$ and
$m'_\gamma=m'_{\gamma,A}$, and so $m''_\gamma=m''_{\gamma,A}$, 
which finishes the
proof of Point~\eqref{th-1-finite} of  Theorem~\ref{th-1-gen} 
in the case $G={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}({\widehat{A}}(\gamma),U,V)$.

To prove the same results when $G={\text{\rm {Opt}}}({\widehat{A}}(\gamma))$, we shall
use the following lemma.

\begin{lemma}
Let $b$ be a matrix polynomial with coefficients in ${\mathbb{C}}^{n\times n}$ and degree $d$,
let $B\in{\mathbb{R}}_{\min}^{n\times n}$ be a min-plus matrix such that ${\operatorname{per}} B\neq{\mathbbold{0}}$,
and let $(U,V)$  be a  Hungarian pair with respect to $B$.
Then, the matrix polynomials $b^{G}:=b_0^G+\cdots + {\mathsf{Y}}^d b_d^G$ defined
respectively with $G={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$ and with $G={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$
have the same eigenvalues.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
Let $\sigma$ be an optimal permutation for $B$.
Then, by Corollary~\ref{coro3}, the identity map is an optimal permutation for 
$C:={P_{\min}^{\sigma^{-1}}} B$, $(U_{\sigma^{-1}},V)$ is  a Hungarian pair with respect to $C$, and we have ${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$,
and ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,U_{\sigma^{-1}},V)={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$.
Then, by Corollary~\ref{coro5},
${\text{\rm {Opt}}}(C)$ is 
 the disjoint union of the strongly connected components
of ${{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(C,U_{\sigma^{-1}},V)$.
Multiplying the matrix polynomials $b$ and $b^G$ on the left by $P^{\sigma^{-1}}$,
and using the above notation, 
we deduce that $P^{\sigma^{-1}} b^{G}=c^{G'}$,
with $c=P^{\sigma^{-1}}b$ and $G'=G_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$.
Since $P^{\sigma^{-1}}$ is invertible, the sequence of eigenvalues
of $b^G$ is the same as the one of  $P^{\sigma^{-1}} b^{G}$,
hence the same as the one of $c^{G'}$.
If $G'$ has several strongly connected components,
then, up to a permutation, the matrix polynomial
$c^{G'}$ is bloc triangular, with diagonal blocs
$c^{S}$, for each strongly connected component $S$ of $G'$.
Then, the sequence of eigenvalues of $c^{G'}$
is the disjoint union of the sequences of eigenvalues of the
matrix polynomials  $c^S$.
Since the sequence of eigenvalues
of $b^G$ is the same as the one of $c^{G'}$,
and, by the above properties, the strongly connected components of 
$G'=G_{\sigma^{-1},{\text{\rm {id}}}}$ are the same for  $G={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ and $G={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$,
we deduce that the sequence of eigenvalues of $b^G$ are the same
for $G={\text{\rm {Opt}}}(B)$ and for $G={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}(B,U,V)$.
\end{proof}
Applying this result to the matrix polynomial 
$b= a_0^{{\mathcal{G}}_{0}(A,\gamma)}+\cdots +{\mathsf{Y}}^d a_d^{{\mathcal{G}}_{d}(A,\gamma)}$, 
and the min-plus matrix $B={\widehat{A}}(\gamma)$,
we get that the matrix polynomials $a^{(\gamma)}$ given in~\eqref{pencilsat},
with $G_k={\mathcal{G}}_{k}(A,\gamma)\cap G$ for all $0\leq k\leq d$,
and respectively $G={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}({\widehat{A}}(\gamma),U,V)$ or $G={\text{\rm {Opt}}}({\widehat{A}}(\gamma))$
have same eigenvalues.
So the assertion of Point~\eqref{th-1-finite} of  Theorem~\ref{th-1} (resp.\ 
Theorem~\ref{th-1-gen}) for $G={{\text{\rm {Sat}}}}({\widehat{A}}(\gamma),U,V)$ 
is equivalent to the one for $G={\text{\rm {Opt}}}({\widehat{A}}(\gamma))$,
which finishes the proof of this point.
